It's possible to quantify gender biases in GPT-3.5 and 4, and there's clear evidence that both systems have difficulty answering questions where gender assumptions run counter to social stereotypes. The likely reason: implicit bias from corpora: https://aisnakeoil.substack.com/p/quantifying-chatgpts-gender-bias

TIL: lace cards

It’s a computer punch card with every possible spot punched out, so what remains is a flimsy filamentous net of paper that instantly tears and jams up the card reader.

Old-school denial of service attack.

https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lace_card

I just read the best paper I've seen yet this year, Sam Zhang's work on confusion between inferential uncertainty and outcome variability.

In the context of a trial or experiment, inferential uncertainty refers to our statistical confidence that two groups are different. Outcome variability refers to how much variation there is in individual outcomes within a single group.

IMO confusion about this is ubiquitous in biomedical science.

Here's the paper: https://osf.io/preprints/socarxiv/5tcgs/

title: Acute and postacute sequelae associated with SARS-CoV-2 reinfection - Nature Medicine

last_post.content:
I was reading today's Nature article, sighing with some of its inevitable tone, sensing a thread coming on, and then looked at the graph provided

https://www.nature.com/articles/s41591-022-02051-3

It looks like its "not much" additional risk. Right?

Its a trap! The risk ratios shown are show log plot, not linear.

Fortunately, @tjradcliffe beat me to it. He replotted the risk ratios into linear.

After the 3rd infection, the hospitalization risk is 40% or 400 per 1000.

Read that again.

#SARS2 #sarscov2 #COVID19

title: Six Centuries of Type & Printing (letterpress and ebook bundle)

last_post.content: Back in 2020, I published Six Centuries of Type & Printing, a concise book – 64 pages – that actually starts centuries before Gutenberg, with Chinese and Korea printing, and then digs into 1450 to 2020, covering ~600 years of technological advances. Set in hot-metal type (Monotype Bembo) in North Yorkshire, printed in London, and bound in Germany with a foil-stamped cover & slipcase, I still have copies available for shipping worldwide! https://glog.glennf.com/tiny-type-museum-time-capsule-and-more/six-centuries-letterpress (ebook edition available)

It's beautiful 😍

Oh my, friends—some wonderful news this morning. I posted a bit ago about Keely Kuester’s "Composing Whitman" #digitalhumanities project, which visualizes the movement of a #letterpress compositor’s hand when setting type:

https://hcommons.social/@ryancordell/110192604143200468

Keely conceived the project for their "Building a (Better) Book" final assignment & has developed it with @TransBookHistory while working this semester at Skeuomorph Press.

Here’s the big news: Keely’s project won first place in #UIUC’s university-wide undergraduate "Image of Research" contest. I’m bursting with pride at this well-deserved recognition!

https://publish.illinois.edu/imageofresearch/undergraduate-image-of-research/2023-undergraduate-entries/

I can’t wait to watch the project continue developing in the future.

title: Don’t Just Tell Me, Ask Me: AI Systems that Intelligently Frame Explanations as Questions Improve Human Logical Discernment Accuracy over Causal AI explanations | Proceedings of the 2023 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems

last_post.content:
Interesting new #CHI2023 paper on human-AI interaction. Key point: in the context of AI-supported decision making, asking a question (“If one person played video games and was aggressive does it follow that everyone that plays violent video games will be aggressive?”) leads to higher quality decisions than suggesting an answer (“If one person played video games and was aggressive, it does not follow that everyone that plays violent video games will be aggressive”).

https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/3544548.3580672
